description: From Middle English hard, from Old English heard, from Proto-West Germanic *hard(ƒ´), from Proto-Germanic *harduz, from Proto-Indo-European *kort-√∫s, from *kret- (‚Äústrong, powerful‚Äù). Cognate with German hart, Swedish h√•rd, Ancient Greek Œ∫œÅŒ±œÑœçœÇ (krat√∫s), Sanskrit ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å (kr√°tu), Avestan ê¨ëê¨≠ê¨Äê¨ôê¨é‚Äé (xratu).

definitionGroups.group: (of material or fluid) Having a severe property; presenting difficulty.

entries.meaning: Resistant to pressure.
examples: This bread is so stale and hard, I can barely cut it.

entries.meaning: (of drink or drugs) Strong.
(of a normally nonalcoholic drink) Containing alcohol.
examples: hard cider, hard lemonade, hard seltzer, hard soda

entries.meaning: (of water) High in dissolved chemical salts, especially those of calcium.
(physics, of a ferromagnetic material) Having the capability of being a permanent magnet by being a material with high magnetic coercivity (compare soft).
(physics, of electromagnetic radiation) Having a high energy (high frequency; short wavelength).
examples: hard X-rays

entries.meaning: (photography, of light) Made up of parallel rays, producing clearly defined shadows.

definitionGroups.group: (personal or social) Having a severe property; presenting difficulty.

entries.meaning: Difficult or requiring a lot of effort to do, understand, experience, or deal with.
examples: a hard problem;‚ÄÉ a hard question;‚ÄÉ a hard topic

entries.meaning: Demanding a lot of effort to endure.
examples: a hard life

entries.meaning: Severe, harsh, unfriendly, brutal.
examples: a hard master;‚ÄÉ a hard heart;‚ÄÉ hard words;‚ÄÉ a hard character
The senator asked the party chief to put the hard word on his potential rivals.

entries.meaning: (dated) Difficult to resist or control; powerful.
(military) Hardened; having unusually strong defences.
examples: a hard site

entries.meaning: (slang) Tough and muscular.
examples: He thinks he's well hard.

entries.meaning: Unquestionable, unequivocal.
examples: hard evidence;‚ÄÉ a hard requirement

entries.meaning: (of a road intersection) Having a comparatively larger or a ninety-degree angle.
examples: At the intersection, there are two roads going to the left. Take the hard left.

entries.meaning: (slang, vulgar, of a male) Sexually aroused; having an erect penis.
examples: I got so hard watching two hot girls wrestle each other on the beach.

entries.meaning: (bodybuilding) Having muscles that are tightened as a result of intense, regular exercise.
Plosive.
examples: There is a hard c in "clock" and a soft c in "centre".

entries.meaning: Unvoiced.
examples: Hard k, t, s, ch, as distinguished from soft, g, d, z, j.

entries.meaning: (Slavic phonology) Velarized or plain, rather than palatalized.
examples: The letter –∂ (≈æ) in Russian is always hard.

definitionGroups.group: (art) Having a severe property; presenting a barrier to enjoyment.

entries.meaning: Rigid in the drawing or distribution of the figures; formal; lacking grace of composition.
Having disagreeable and abrupt contrasts in colour or shading.
In a physical form, not digital.
examples: a soft or hard copy; a digital or hard archive

entries.meaning: Using a manual or physical process, not by means of a software command.
examples: a hard reboot or reset

entries.meaning: (politics) Far, extreme.
examples: hard right, hard left

entries.meaning: Of silk: not having had the natural gum boiled off.
(finance) Of a market: having more demand than supply; being a seller's market.
examples: Antonym: soft

entries.meaning: (of pornography) hardcore
(manner) With much force or effort.
examples: He hit the puck hard up the ice.
They worked hard all week.
At the intersection, bear hard left.
The recession hit them especially hard.
Think hard about your choices.
The couple were fucking each other hard.

entries.meaning: (manner) With difficulty.
examples: His degree was hard earned.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) So as to raise difficulties.
(manner) Compactly.
examples: The lake had finally frozen hard.

entries.meaning: (now archaic) Near, close.
examples: [‚Ä¶] whose house joined hard to the synagogue.

entries.meaning: (countable, nautical) A firm or paved beach or slope convenient for hauling vessels out of the water.
examples: The Monastery's ironworks at Sowley were renowned for centuries but declined with the passing of the 'wooden walls' at Buckler's Hard ‚Äî a great number of these ships having been built with timber from the Beaulieu Woods  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (countable, motorsports) A tyre whose compound is softer than superhards, and harder than mediums.
(uncountable, drugs, slang) Crack cocaine.
(uncountable, slang) Hard labor.
examples: The prisoners were sentenced to three years' hard.
